subject: Re: [junit] Bertrand Meyer's approach (Contract-Driven Development)
msgSnippet: ... He appears to have nothing to say on that; he mentions Contract-Driven Development not once in the entire interview. Contract Driven DESIGN is an
messageBody:
On Wed, 10 Mar 2004, haefeleuser wrote:

> I have only read the summary until now. Maybe you are interested in
> what he has to say in favor of Contract-Driven Development.

He appears to have nothing to say on that; he mentions "Contract-Driven
Development" not once in the entire interview.

Contract Driven DESIGN is an excellent idea when you're designing stuff
far in advance, and you need to constrain how people use things years
down the road. Having the compiler enforce what would otherwise be
documentation (e.g., "this method must never return an integer smaller
than zero") is great.

But doing this level of design is probably a waste of time for classes
used within a single project when you're doing XP; just write the thing
and make it good enough, and get it out of the way; if something changes
later you can just go back and change the class as you wish. There's no
need to do a lot of design for future issues.

I don't see how DBC is going to drive your coding style the way that
TDD does, since DBC is not even about coding; it's about design before
coding.

cjs

Don't you know, in this new Dark Age, we're all light. --XTC
